stream_context.summary: Kaze spent the entire session inside Course 15, “Astro Arcade,” modelling and coding its pinball-style gimmick parts (flippers, bumpers, trampolines) while reflecting on tester feedback from earlier courses and demo planning.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 is the final main course; three side levels and the overworlds remain before content lock.
Astro Arcade’s core gimmicks are five interactable pieces: rotating flipper, spherical bumper, triangular direction bumper, static metal platform (visuals to be redesigned), and vertical trampoline.
development_findings.quote: We’ll be programming all of these next: flipper, bumper, direction triangle, metal stand-ons, and the spring pad.

development_findings.summary: Beta testing of Course 3 revealed players miss the intended path and find the 8-bit pipe too early; Kaze plans visual guidance (signs, easier gap, pipe visible but inaccessible at first).
development_findings.quote: The overall conclusion is the player really needs to be guided to Star 1 a lot more.

development_findings.summary: Flipper code now scales Mario’s velocity upward and gives temporary air control; gravity bias was added so side hits still shoot the player mostly upward.
Star pads will change brightness on impact; Biobak will propose the exact blink pattern.
‘Metal’ pinball pieces are being scrapped or re-textured; Kaze seeks an arcade-carpet visual language instead.
Kaze is removing the word “nipper” from a textbox after multiple testers interpreted it as a slur.
Demo build plan: Course 1 + Delfino-Plaza overworld with signs explaining controls; testers praise new camera/controls.
development_findings.quote: Everyone that played the demo thought that the new controls and camera were great.

development_findings.summary: Technical: game requires Expansion Pak for convenience; framebuffer memory split for speed; Kaze discovered an extra 1 MB of hidden RAM (topic of next video) that doesn’t work on emulators.
development_findings.quote: We found a way to use an extra one megabyte in the N64, and it doesn’t work on emulators.

development_findings.summary: Considering a bubble or checkpoint item to soften void deaths; undecided on universal implementation.
Nintendo takedown risk shapes marketing — trailer must be unmistakably fair-use and may avoid cartridges.
development_findings.quote: With the release trailer, I want to be very careful, because I feel like Nintendo is going to try to take that down.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values clear player onboarding, citing Mario 64’s ‘obvious first star’ philosophy.
context_findings.quote: I think that’s why all the Mario 64 levels are designed the way they are… it gets your foot in the door.

context_findings.summary: Expressed frustration with Canadian social niceties and casual racism in chat; playful but pointed.
Excitement about upcoming 14-minute YouTube video; believes it’s his best yet.
context_findings.quote: Dude, we just finished the next video. It’s 14 minutes long and it’s a banger.

context_findings.summary: Long technical rants (cache, quantum data) show his enthusiasm for pushing N64 limits beyond typical rom-hacking.
Jokes about ethically questionable projects (Unreal port, meme coin) reveal awareness of community’s legal/ethical grey zones.

biobak.summary: Provided the demo overworld model; Kaze reviewed it on-stream.
Will design the visual logic for the flipper star blink and pitched ‘ball tube’ concept.
Acts as sounding board for texture ideas and signage readability.

badub.summary: Holds original sound assets; Kaze directs viewers to Badub for unused SFX and flute requests.

zeina.summary: Active in chat; questioned ‘ugly’ metal piece; brief on-stream cameo delivering hot chocolate and checking in.

key_stories.title: Testers Lost in Course 3
key_stories.summary: One tester spent 25 minutes, earned one star, and quit. Kaze analysed the session and listed concrete fixes.
key_stories.challenge: Player failed to notice the main path and struggled with the 8-bit pipe and initial gap.
key_stories.process: Kaze rewatched footage, wrote a to-do list: hide pipe at first, add clearer visual cues, simplify jumps.
key_stories.outcome: Design pivot toward a guided first-star path; influences current and future level layouts.
key_stories.key_quote: The player really needs to be guided to Star 1 a lot more.

key_stories.title: Hidden Megabyte Discovery
key_stories.summary: Kaze exploited a ninth RAM bit to access 1 MB of undocumented N64 memory.
key_stories.challenge: Need more RAM without sacrificing expansion-pack compatibility.
key_stories.process: Experimented with cache instructions and segmented framebuffers.
key_stories.outcome: Works on real hardware but breaks emulators; forms basis of upcoming video and may stay optional in hack.
key_stories.key_quote: We found a way to use an extra one megabyte in the N64, and it doesn’t work on emulators.

key_stories.title: Flipper Piece Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Implemented fully functional pinball flipper object after iterative coding live on stream.
key_stories.challenge: Object needed to rotate, scale, impart consistent upward force from any angle, and feel intuitive.
key_stories.process: Tested scaling errors, corrected pitch bias, added air-control and sound, debated star-blink feedback.
key_stories.outcome: Core gimmick for Course 15 finished; opens speed-tech possibilities.
key_stories.key_quote: This feels very controllable to me, but I’m also the guy that programmed it.
